title: Test for first post
text:
This is a test for the first post.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

title: second post
text:
So who is actually good at football in the Big Ten? Turns out, it’s not the school you’re thinking of.
Loading libraries and data first


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(paletteer)
library(showtext)


Loading required package: sysfonts
Loading required package: showtextdb


Code
font_add_google("Montserrat", "montserrat")
showtext_auto()




Code
logs2024 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
logs2025 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
big10 <- c("Nebraska Cornhuskers", "Iowa Hawkeyes", "Minnesota Golden Gophers", "Illinois Fighting Illini", "Northwestern Wildcats", "Wisconsin Badgers", "Indiana Hoosiers", "Purdue Boilermakers", "Ohio State Buckeyes", "Michigan Wolverines", "Michigan State Spartans", "Penn State Nittany Lions", "Rutgers Scarlet Knights", "Maryland Terrapins", "Washinton Huskies", "UCLA Bruins", "USC Trojans", "Oregon Ducks")


bigten2024 <- logs2024 |> filter(TeamFull %in% big10)
bigten2025 <- logs2025 |> filter(TeamFull %in% big10)



Finding the Big Ten’s best scoring offenses
To be clear, this is not a fan blog. We here at this publication dedicated to whatever Derek assigned me to do this week are committed to impactful journalism with complete and utter objectivity.
But the author of this post did attend Indiana University for his undergrad years, and may have a bit of a soft spot for this specific dataset which is just 2024 and 2025 data and — as of writing this post before Indiana plays Oregon this weekend — this is undoubtedly the most incredible stretch of Indiana football success in the history of the program. It isn’t even close for the team with the most losses in the history of the sport at a Division I level. So given the rare opportunity we have to discuss Hoosier football glory, let’s see just how good Indiana has been relative to a league that has produced the last two national champions and three of the last four teams to play in the national title game (Indiana beat two of those teams during the span of this dataset).
Okay maybe this is actually a fan blog.
Let’s look first at which Big Ten teams had the best scoring offenses in each of the 2024 and 2025 seasons. Let’s start with 2024. And yes, I made sure to check Indiana’s branding guide for the correct crimson color hex code.


Code
bigten2024 |> 
  group_by(TeamFull) |> 
  summarize(points_per_game = mean(Points, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  arrange(desc(points_per_game)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(TeamFull, points_per_game), y = points_per_game)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#990000") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Indiana leads Big Ten scoring offenses in 2024... by a lot", subtitle = "Five Big Ten surpassed 30 point per game averages in the 2024 season. Four of them made the College Football Playoff. But only one team — Indiana — surpassed the 40 point per game threshold.", y = "Points per game", x = "") +
   theme_minimal() +
  theme(
  axis.title = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
    title = element_text(size = 13, family = "montserrat", face="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 9, face = "plain"),
    plot.caption = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 8, face = "italic"),
  axis.text = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
  )









Indiana averaged 41.31 points per game in 2024. That’s the clear leader among Big Ten teams (for what it’s worth, that was also second best nationally behind Miami — and nothing at all went wrong for Miami in 2024 obviously!). The next closest is Ohio State at 35.69. That’s certainly a notable gap!
Should we mention that Ohio State still beat Indiana and went on to win the national championship? I guess that’s probably important to note that scoring a lot of points doesn’t make you the BEST team. But it doesn’t hurt!
Now let’s look at 2025. What changed, if anything?


Code
bigten2025 |> 
  group_by(TeamFull) |> 
  summarize(points_per_game = mean(Points, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  arrange(desc(points_per_game)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(TeamFull, points_per_game), y = points_per_game)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#990000") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "New faces join the Big Ten's top scoring offenses.", subtitle = "USC currently leads the Big Ten in scoring offense, but some less regarded teams like Nebraska have made big surges in 2025 compared to a season ago. Indiana still remains in the top two. But this time is indeed two.", y = "Points per game", x = "") +
   theme_minimal() +
  theme(
  axis.title = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
    title = element_text(size = 13, family = "montserrat", face="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 9, face = "plain"),
    plot.caption = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 8, face = "italic"),
  axis.text = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
  )









There are also a lot big scoring numbers at the top of the chart here. There are four teams averaging more than 40 points so far this year.
So is scoring up this year?


Code
b1g2025ptsavg <- bigten2025 |> 
  summarize(avgpts = mean(Points, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  pull(avgpts)

b1g2024ptsavg <- bigten2024 |> 
  summarize(avgpts = mean(Points, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  pull(avgpts)

pct_change <- ((b1g2025ptsavg - b1g2024ptsavg) / b1g2024ptsavg) * 100

avg_data <- tibble(
  Year = c(2024, 2025),
  Average = c(b1g2024ptsavg, b1g2025ptsavg)
)

ggplot(avg_data, aes(x = factor(Year), y = Average, group = 1)) +
  geom_line(color = "#990000", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3, color = "#990000") +
  labs(
    title = "Scoring in the Big Ten is up in 2025",
    subtitle = "But this data isn't balanced yet. It is comparing the full 2024 season against the first five games in 2025.",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average Points"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
  axis.title = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
    title = element_text(size = 13, family = "montserrat", face="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 9, face = "plain"),
    plot.caption = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 8, face = "italic"),
  axis.text = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
  )









Scoring is up about 27% in the Big Ten this year. Granted, most of the games played are still non-conference games so we can’t really compare that number too much given the higher unbalanced sample size of cupcake games relative to power conference opponents.
So let’s check that out.


Code
b1g2025ptsavg <- bigten2025 |> 
  summarize(avgpts = mean(Points, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  pull(avgpts)

adjustedb1g2024ptsavg <- bigten2024 |> filter(Gtm <= 5) |> 
  summarize(avgpts = mean(Points, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  pull(avgpts)

adjusted_pct_change <- ((b1g2025ptsavg-adjustedb1g2024ptsavg)/adjustedb1g2024ptsavg)*100

avg_data <- tibble(
  Year = c(2024, 2025),
  Average = c(adjustedb1g2024ptsavg, b1g2025ptsavg)
)

ggplot(avg_data, aes(x = factor(Year), y = Average, group = 1)) +
  geom_line(color = "#990000", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3, color = "#990000") +
  labs(
    title = "Even with adjusted data, scoring is still up in 2025",
    subtitle = "Through the first five games of both the 2024 and 2025 seasons, this year's average scoring in the Big Ten is up by about five points per game.",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average Points"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
  axis.title = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
    title = element_text(size = 13, family = "montserrat", face="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 9, face = "plain"),
    plot.caption = element_text(family = "montserrat", size = 8, face = "italic"),
  axis.text = element_text(size = 6, family = "montserrat", face = "bold"),
  )









Turns out scoring is still up over the first games of the season (balanced where being five games into the 2025 season), but quite a bit less than 27%. 17.4% is still a pretty big jump in scoring through.
And Indiana is still second in the Big Ten. The Hoosiers are scoring 47.8 points per game so far, less than a point behind Big Ten leaders USC.

title: Post With Code
text: This is a post with executable code.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: second post
text:
So who is actually good at football in the Big Ten? Turns out, it’s not the school you’re thinking of.
Loading libraries and data first


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1

✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

title: Big Ten average plays
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(paletteer)
library(showtext)


Loading required package: sysfonts
Loading required package: showtextdb


Code
font_add_google("Montserrat", "montserrat")
showtext_auto()

logs2024 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
logs2025 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
big10 <- c("Nebraska Cornhuskers", "Iowa Hawkeyes", "Minnesota Golden Gophers", "Illinois Fighting Illini", "Northwestern Wildcats", "Wisconsin Badgers", "Indiana Hoosiers", "Purdue Boilermakers", "Ohio State Buckeyes", "Michigan Wolverines", "Michigan State Spartans", "Penn State Nittany Lions", "Rutgers Scarlet Knights", "Maryland Terrapins", "Washinton Huskies", "UCLA Bruins", "USC Trojans", "Oregon Ducks")


bigten2024 <- logs2024 |> filter(TeamFull %in% big10)
bigten2025 <- logs2025 |> filter(TeamFull %in% big10)




Code
b1g2024plays <- bigten2024 |> 
  group_by(TeamFull) |> 
  summarise(totalplays = sum(TotalPlays), avgplays = mean(TotalPlays)) |> 
  arrange(desc(totalplays))
            

b1g2025plays <- bigten2025 |> 
  group_by(TeamFull) |> 
  summarise(totalplays = sum(TotalPlays), avgplays = mean(TotalPlays)) |> 
  arrange(desc(totalplays))

combinedplays <- b1g2024plays |> 
  inner_join(b1g2025plays, by = "TeamFull", suffix = c("2024", "2025")) |>
  mutate(combined_total = totalplays2024 + totalplays2025,
         combined_avg = (avgplays2024 + avgplays2025) / 2) 

b1g2024plays


# A tibble: 17 × 3
   TeamFull                 totalplays avgplays
   <chr>                         <dbl>    <dbl>
 1 Penn State Nittany Lions       1052     65.8
 2 Ohio State Buckeyes             989     61.8
 3 Oregon Ducks                    959     68.5
 4 Rutgers Scarlet Knights         912     70.2
 5 USC Trojans                     900     69.2
 6 Nebraska Cornhuskers            883     67.9
 7 Maryland Terrapins              864     72  
 8 Indiana Hoosiers                852     65.5
 9 Minnesota Golden Gophers        816     62.8
10 Illinois Fighting Illini        805     61.9
